abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA)
            reviews the institutional framework concerning environmental
            protection policies, and programs related with housing
            construction, to recommend actions to mitigate environmental
            adversity that may result from implementation of the
            Affordable Housing and Urban Poverty Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project in Mexico. From an institutional perspective,
            the report suggests active participation by environmental
            authorities in the housing sector, on policy planning, and
            implementation, supported by a strong legal, and regulatory
            framework. To this end, the conflicts between federal, and
            state programs should be addressed, to then establish
            mechanisms strengthening housing information management
            systems for the provision of housing environmental
            indicators, low-income housing costs, and housing market
            estimates. Housing development should initially consider
            availability of water resources, promote as possible water
            tariffs that reflect real costs, as well as infrastructure
            costs that support water service delivery, and, include an
            adequate water management, and sanitation technology for
            current construction programs, supported by training and
            capacity building. Similarly, power consumption indicators
            should be made available, so that construction plans are in
            accordance with the energy supply. From the urban
            standpoint, roads and urban transportation modes should be
            fostered, taking into account the necessary legal and
            regulatory framework concerning an integrated urban program.
